page.title: 08Scot's Dike Earthwork.
page.content: Scot's Dike is the name given to an earthwork which extends from North Yorkshire and into Durham and Northumberland for 70 miles. It is several metres high in places and was probably a boundary between tribes in pre-Roman days. In the Richmond town plan the council have decided that housing development should be controlled to avoid destruction of the Dike. Every 7 years the Mayor,Aldermen and councillors,led by the Town Crier,two Sergeants-at-Mace and and the Pinder or pioneer,with an axe, perambulate the boundaries of the Borough,starting at the Green bridge.It takes all day with a stop for lunch. The Dike forms the eastern boundary of the town.The last boundary riding took place in 1983.
